response.overview: A Khata (ཁ་བཏགས) is a ceremonial scarf used throughout the Himalayan world, commemorating births, weddings, graduations, and the arrival and departure of guests. Presenting a Khata is viewed as a symbol of respect, gratitude, and pure motives. What happens when a sacred object, like the Khata, becomes ubiquitous? Today, the most common raw material for the Khata is a synthetic chemical fiber called polyester. Due to the widespread use of Khata in everyday life, discarded Khata can be found in rivers and lakes all across the larger Himalayan world. Many animals die from eating them, and fish and birds can get caught and die in their threads. This ethnographic documentary film explores the paradoxical relationship between the meaning of Khata and its materiality, between purity and poison, with the aim of raising awareness of the unintended consequences of our good intentions.
response.title: Khata
